[],This PR merely renames the splunk logging components to something that sounds a little more generic. While using the splunk product was the inspiration behind the components, we didn't want developers to feel like they needed splunk deployed in order to log in a key-value pair style.

,244500741,1549,Unable to encrypt passwords with special characters '$', while configuring Code Repo Dashboard",2017-07-20 21:22:47,2018-09-18 14:39:35,closed,3,kumarvarun1252,,"316877664 @kumarvarun1252
pls help me how to set up password encryption and decryption for private repo and where i need to setup in application.properties, etc. kindly share detailed steps.
Go to Hygieia-Master -> UI and open README.md.
Scroll to the end and you will get, Encryption for private repos
Now generate this key and add it to the properties file of both api and github i.e
Hygieia-master -> api -> target -> (properties file) -> key = (new generated private key )
Hygieia-master -> collectors ->scm -> github -> target -> open your properties file ->github.key = (new generated private key )
This key will help you encrypt & decrypt your credentials .
Now run api then gulp serve then collectors.
If You Are Using GHE - (Enterprise Github)

**ask your IT to provide you with username and password to bypass the enterprise (GHE) login. GHE logins are different as compared to that of normal github logins as you enter your Windows login or LDAP or (many options). if you dont have such login then your collector should perform properly.
I had previously been unsuccessful in getting GHE populating my dashboard but now I have figured out. Hope you have got everything, any doubts do ask me . golokeshpatra45
317581871 @golokeshpatra45 thanks for the information. I don't see the error after setting up the encryption.
I guess the error message displayed ""Error encrypting password"" should be modified to something more descriptive and informative. kumarvarun1252

Can we set proxy in github collector in hygieia? ashu5993
Go to Hygieia-Master -> UI and open README.md.
Scroll to the end and you will get, Encryption for private repos
Now generate this key and add it to the properties file of both api and github i.e
Hygieia-master -> api -> target -> (properties file) -> key = (new generated private key )
Hygieia-master -> collectors ->scm -> github -> target -> open your properties file ->github.key = (new generated private key )
This key will help you encrypt your credentials .
Now run api then gulp serve then collectors.

**ask your IT to provide you with username and password to bypass the enterprise (GHE) login. GHE logins are different as compared to that of normal github logins as you enter your Windows login or LDAP or (many options).
If you dont have such login then your collector should perform properly without doing the above.
I had been unsuccessful in getting GHE populating my dashboard but now I have figured out. Hope you have got everything, any doubts do ask me . golokeshpatra45

314382963 Found the route course to this issue. This is not a problem with Hygieia. The issue is with the GitLab configurations.

To get commits from configured GitLab account, Hygieia GitLab collector calls https://git.company.com/api/v3/projects/namespace%2Fprojectname/repository/commits/?ref_name=branch&since=date&per_page=100. But to use namespace/projectname (with URL encoding it would be namespace%2Fprojectname) in the API call, GitLab Apache should be configured with **AllowEncodedSlashes NoDecode** to ensure that encoded slashes are not decoded but left in their encoded state.
But when you are using an enterprise GitLab without no access to change GitLab server configurations, what would be the solution?
> get the GitLab project id and when configuring GitLab widget in Hygieia, provide the repo URL as https://git.xxxxxx.com/projectid.git. mdinuth

314461588 Ah, haven't seen anyone with that issue before.  To make this work you would need to change a few things to allow either a project id, or namespace and project name.  One of the things I would like to change in the future is make the configuration more specific to what it's collecting from.  For github and gitlab, there is no need to put in the entire url, all you really need is the namespace and project, or the project id.  I imagine we request the url because that's what you would need for SVN, but it isn't a great user experience for git repos.  rob-miller-777
401387796 @mdinuth @rob-miller-777 I am running into a similar issue https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/2311 and this hack didnt work-
get the GitLab project id and when configuring GitLab widget in Hygieia, provide the repo URL as https://git.xxxxxx.com/projectid.git.
313107448 Does the api token your providing have access to that repo? rob-miller-777
313364318 Yes. API token is correct. I verified the token by taking a git pull as below.
313511084 Is the repo nested inside multiple subgroups? rob-miller-777
313586025 It is under xxx group. Not inside subgroups. mdinuth

[],New functionality keeps getting added to collectors, such as the Github collector retrieving issues, comments, and pull requests. However these changes don't get applied to the other collectors such as gitlab and subversion.  Because of this, all the SCM collectors have different functionality.  What would you think about adding another abstract class, or an interface that all collectors of a type would have to extend/implement.  For example, for the SCM collectors, they could extend a new ScmCollectorTask, which would have methods you have to implement for collecting commits, issues, etc... We could create these for all the different types as well.  That way when new functionality is added, it will force all the collectors to stay in sync. In cases such as subversion where there is no concept of ""issues"", it would just be a ""noop"" for the implementation of that method.  It will also provide a consistent structure for creating new collectors. Documenting issue.,236632041,1485,Upgrade apache commons-lang to latest version 3.6,2017-06-17 02:02:33,2018-09-18 14:39:29,closed,3,chtompki,,309186378 Note anything using the package `org.apache.commons.lang.*` is quite old and *should* be upgraded to using `org.apache.commons.lang3` the 3.x line of commons-lang. Furthermore, this is generalized across all apache commons libraries, where the package gets versioned along with major version changes for the ability to consume two different major versions of a component. However, that is merely a mechanism for migration.
Thus all of these might be worth addressing:
309186470 Why are we versioning jars independently in their individual components, and not in the parent? Couldn't' this cause notable classpath collisions? chtompki

1) Add Business Services and Business Applications to dashboards.
2) Update Business Services and Business Applications for dashboards
3) Now shows the Application Name on the dashboard screen and Main page
4) User can now search by Application Name/ Business Service or Business Application on Main page search
5) Validation will not allow more than one dashboard with the same Business Service and Business Application to be created
Dashboard will now show Application Name if no Business Service or Business Application is selected.

419647691 what was the solution, if you can elaborate a bit, it may help many. Seems like i am having same issue. Sandeep-Mandori
419657355 Well, in my case it was 2 things (that I remember so far)
1. I registered my collector under a different name (than Jira) and that was causing an issue when showing it in the UI

2. The core project wasn't updated to reflect the new properties I added for the Feature model and I had to update it (core project) then update its dependency within the API project so the UI could finally pick the missing data
They put a bit of information around the schema here
But yeah basically is that if you make changes to a collector you gotta follow the chain

[],Started to implement a v2 of the rest API.  Before we started to do the entire thing, we wanted to get a small piece out there to get some feedback on, so we rewrote the ""Dashboards"" controller.  We followed what we had mentioned in #1444 , and implemented v2 using Spring's hateoas library.  You will notice upon making a get request to ""/api/v2/"", the response will contain links to resources in the application.  Right now there are only a couple relating to dashboards, but eventually there will be more as more controllers are added.  Making a get request to the dashboards endpoint will give you the list of dashboards, and each of the dashboards will have a link to itself.  We also updated swagger to separate v1 from v2, so you can see the different versions of the api.  We tried to avoid making changes to the backend services as much as possible, but there were a couple small changes that had to be made to make this work properly, but nothing that breaks backwards compatibility. 368036325 Easiest is to delete the cookie called JSESSIONID for <hygeiea-url>/api.  cahi

13. Refresh the dashboard to view the data.

[],Currently, the modal to edit ownership of a dashboard only checks to see if the user is currently an admin of the application, and makes the user an admin if the case is no. When a user is promoted to a dashboard 'admin', they are inadvertently promoted to an admin for the entire application. For more detail, I will define what I believe to be an 'owner' vs an 'admin'.
* Able to edit widget configuration for dashboards **they own**
* Able to edit owners list for dashboards **they own**
* Able to edit widget configuration for **all** dashboards
* Able to edit owners list for **all** dashboards
In this PR I have reduced the scope of promoting someone from an application admin, to an owner of the specific dashboard, as well as some minor cleanup (wording, method redundancy, etc).
@tabladrum @satishc1 ",232989626,1446,Promoting Dashboard User to Dashboard Owner,2017-06-01 19:44:57,2018-09-18 14:39:25,closed,1,brennanananan,,"306312118 @tabladrum LGTM satishc1

[],Want to take a stab at a V2 of the API. Based on your roadmap, it looks like you wanted to create a more intelligent API, here were some thoughts I had for enhancements.
- Take advantage of Spring HATEOAS, and make the API self discoverable through use of link and proper rest nouns/verbs.  Will be more consistent and easier to navigate.

- Separate the domain model from the rest api resources.  Currently, the client needs to have more knowledge of the domain than it should have to.  Since Hygieia has been around a while now, we have a better understanding of the use cases, which should give us a better understanding of what resources we will need to expose.
- Instead of removing the old API, create a V2 we could slowly migrate to.  This would most likely be accomplished through the url.  ex. ""http:/localhost/api/v2/foo""
Let me know if you guys have any thoughts on this, or would like to see anything else.
,305601739 Yeah, was definitely going to keep that in mind as we go.  rob-miller-777
305680654 There is some discussion on gitter regarding some changes needed to receive ""Comcast"" contributions like Rally collector and some others they built. irvingoe
305788526 @irvingoe I believe that one involves changing Hygieia from a monolithic git project to a submodule git project, which might be a bit beyond the scope of this particular issue.

We could certainly split the API out into it's own project, though - that might make it easier for individuals to set up and make localized contributions to just the API. The same could be said about the UI - if all you want to do is make a few aesthetic improvements, you (theoretically) wouldn't have to set up a ton of stuff to make that contribution. Of course, there might be greater maintainer load associated with this approach. I think #1305 is more appropriate for these discussions :)
@rob-miller-777 totally onboard with all of the above ideas, though. mrpudn
305790712 fyi... we are looking into having Hygieia as an org. It will help breaking things easily. Stay tuned.  tabladrum
454506656 Long term goal is to create GraphQL api layer. Closing this. tabladrum

305600175 I'd also like to decouple the collector's from the database by having them use the API instead. This should hopefully make it a bit easier for individuals to build/maintain collectors. mrpudn

Go to Hygieia-Master -> UI and open README.md.
Scroll to the end and you will get,  Encryption for private repos
Now generate this key and add it to the properties file of both api and github i.e
Hygieia-master -> api -> target -> (properties file) -> key = (new generated private key )
Hygieia-master -> collectors ->scm -> github -> target -> open your properties file ->github.key = (new generated private key )
This key will help you encrypt your credentials .
Now run api then gulp serve then collectors.

**ask your IT to provide you with username and password to bypass the enterprise (GHE) login. GHE logins are different as compared to that of normal github logins as you enter your Windows login or LDAP or (many options). if you dont have such login then your collector should perform properly.

304955484 @brennanananan and I have done some digging, and we think we have found a problem.  It looks like how this would work, is you would create an API key, which you would then use to login to receive a JWT.  We feel as though this wouldn't be an ideal pattern, you would probably want to utilize one or the other.  Here are the two options we are thinking.

Create an api key pretty much exactly how you are currently doing it.  Give the API key to the applications/jenkins plugins you want to access the api.  These applications would send the api key in the authorization header with each request to login.  Each time a request is sent, the api key would be checked to make sure it was still valid.  Would require some changes and new filters to work, and it is also stateful as the API now has to manage keys.

Modify the create token to create a JWT which you could give to an application.  The JWT would be good for a specific amount of time.  You could control at creation time the permission the JWT would have.  It would be very similar to authorization tokens Github uses. The benefits of this would be that it is similar to how the rest of the application already works, therefor wouldn't require many changes.  It is also stateless since it's a JWT. rob-miller-777

It looks like how this would work, is you would create an API key, which you would then use to login to receive a JWT.""  Correct.. that is the intended pattern. I've highlighted below the benefits of the pattern.. which you have already listed in your options.

**_Create an api key pretty much exactly how you are currently doing it. Give the API key to the applications/jenkins plugins you want to access the api. These applications would send the api key in the authorization header with each request to login. Each time a request is sent, the api key would be checked to make sure it was still valid._** Would require some changes and new filters to work, and it is also stateful as the API now has to manage keys.

Modify the create token to create a JWT which you could give to an application. The JWT would be good for a specific amount of time. You could control at creation time the permission the JWT would have. It would be very similar to authorization tokens Github uses. **_The benefits of this would be that it is similar to how the rest of the application already works, therefor wouldn't require many changes. It is also stateless since it's a JWT_**.

304975700 How do you see this working from the jenkins plugin perspective, or anything that would want to use this pattern?  Would you give the jenkins plugin the API token, and it would login and receive a JWT each time it runs, and then use the JWT token to validate the request? Wouldn't it just be easier to send the API token with each request instead? rob-miller-777

304979272 @rob-miller-777 Thats the way I envisioned it. I went back and forth on the options you had listed  when I was creating this and settled on this pattern because it seemed to have the best of both worlds. satishc1
304980114 I'm just worried about it from a consumption perspective, I don't believe this is a common pattern.   rob-miller-777

304983156 @rob-miller-777 I only see benefits using this pattern because it fits how we are currently using it in Hygieia. The beauty of the JWT token is its stateless so we definitely want it in the picture. But we don't want to assign an indefinite expiration to it. satishc1
304984924 @rob-miller-777 Can you take this for a spin and mull it over some? I'll wait to merge this. Definitely want your opinion on this. Thanks. satishc1

304999426 I like the idea of using JWT tokens and setting an expiration of your choosing for that token.  Could make it very similar to github in being able to assign the permissions it has as well.   rob-miller-777
305000292 @rob-miller-777 Yeah, but we talked about that here https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/1386 but decided against that route. satishc1

305201136 Right, I thought we had agreed on using API tokens instead of JWT.  The combination of the two is what I have a hard time getting on board with. From a consumption perspective, I would expect to be given a token which I could attach as a header to use as my authorization.  I don't think it's a good idea for a consuming app to need to make two calls to access a resource, when it really only needs to make one. rob-miller-777
305203027 @rob-miller-777 @tabladrum Ok no worries. Let me see how big of a code change it will be and then decide whether or not to merge it and refactor later. satishc1
305204892 Would be good to get some other opinions on this as well. rob-miller-777

306060464 @rob-miller-777 @MarkRx @tabladrum Changed the apitoken auth to not require a second JWT call.  The api module readme details how to create the basic auth header for secured api calls. WebSecurityConfig will need the appropriate antMatcher with the particular api end point for example
Which api end points to secure could be left to the users based on some api property. satishc1

306204101 Currently pretty much all gets are unsecured, and all posts require authentication besides the ones for the jenkins plugins, which we made exceptions for in the web security config.  I would say we remove the exceptions once the jenkins plugin has the ability to send an api token with the request. rob-miller-777
306207144 I'm also a little concerned about the token itself.  It looks like you are calling it basic auth, which would be username/password.  I was thinking the header would be something like,
306210625 @rob-miller-777 Correct. Once the jenkin plugin handles tokens we will circle back and clear out the TODOs in WebSecurityConfig. satishc1
306211754 Going to have to make sure to advertise that properly as it will break that interaction until people upgrade their plugin and provide an api key. rob-miller-777

306219125 @rob-miller-777 Agreed. We should do a release of a new jenkins plugin first which requires a token and that can be checked during the test connection piece. We'll give it some time before we actually restrict the APIs on the hygieia side. satishc1

[],With more and more properties being added, it's getting very difficult to manage all the properties in a clean way.  We have come across multiple issues with docker properties builders, and the complexity will only get worse as more are added.  There is also an issue with redundancy, as can be seen with the mongo settings that are repeated for all the collectors, as well as the API.  @Mpluya had opened a pull request #1138 to utilize spring cloud config, which would definitely reduce the amount of redundant properties.  It could also remove the need for the docker properties builders which has a lot of complexity in the scripts.  We have been talking about this, and our ideal state would be below.

Add the dependency for spring cloud config.  We could add the codebase for a spring cloud config server to Hygieia's codebase, as seen in #1138 , or we could have that outside the project all together.  We could then let the cloud config server manage all the properties, and have those loaded on startup.

Begin to shift properties from the cloud config server to an admin page on Hygieia's UI.  The end state would ideally be the cloud config server having the mongo properties, and then each collector could get the other properties from the database after connection.  This would allow you to modify things like jenkins servers, or gitlab host from the UI, instead of properties files.  This would not need to be done all at once, and could potentially be moved over in parts.  This would remove the need for the properties builder, and potentially the need for dockerfiles altogether through use of docker maven plugin configuration.
Would appreciate some feedback and your thoughts.

,303997676 I still am in favor of putting it in the API. The purpose of an API layer is to do this very thing. Hence you will see that existing SDLC tools all have config rest endpoints within their API layers. Plus by having it in the API you can more readily interact with model changes that need to happen when a config changes. Suppose a config change requires updating existing documents. How would you do that in a separate server without rewriting the business logic?

The context root problem is easy to fix and the config server should only be accessible by the admin role. A few more config calls isn't that much of a problem and performance really is an issue just use horizontal scaling of the API and UI layers. You'll have a dependency either way - API or cloud config server.

As for docker properties (as well as command line properties) you will need a phase in period. Phase 1 could be to insert all the properties data into config objects when the collectors start that is accessible but not modifiable by the UI. After some time has passed turn on modification and remove the command line props. If the config is going to go into the database then it should be all or nothing - starting with command line properties should be removed. MarkRx

304014273 Just so we are on the same page, when we create the admin functionality for making configuration changes, I am all for those calls being in the API app.  The cloud config server is just a standalone server that reads configuration files from a git repo, and serves them up to applications asking for them. Our end goal is to have a cloud config server that manages all the configuration that won't change, such as Mongo connection settings.  Anything we want to be dynamic, Sonar servers, Jenkins servers, etc..., would be stored in the MongoDB, and modifiable and retrievable through the UI/API.   rob-miller-777

304018920 Also, we can't store the Mongo connection information inside Mongo for obvious reasons, so we would need some way to get it to the application.  I'm not saying cloud config is the only way, but it is super easy to setup, and offers some awesome functionality.  The same config server can hold the connection information for all environments of Hygieia your organization would have, and can give you the appropriate mongo info based on your spring profile.   rob-miller-777

304053182 What if we were to not include a cloud config server inside the codebase, but just added the 1 dependency necessary to the 'core' project, that would make all the apps look for a cloud collector on startup.  You would just need to pass the apps the name of the application, and uri of the config server at startup.  We could also make using the properties builder optional somehow, because you wouldn't need both.  I could get a branch out there showing what that would look like if you wanted to see it, really shouldn't be more than a couple file changes. rob-miller-777

304342773 Take a look at this.  All I did was add the cloud config dependency which will trigger spring to look for a cloud config server at startup of all the apps, if none are found it continues on normally.  I also added a condition to the properties builder to skip if a property is set so it is no longer required if you plan on utilizing cloud config.  So the only real difference here is it no looks for a cloud config server on startup, but if not found, no change. All you would have to do for the cloud config server to work is provide the `spring.application.name`, which corresponds to the properties files the config server holds. And also `spring.cloud.config.uri` if it exists anywhere besides `http://localhost:8888`, which is the default location.

303262587 @rob-miller-777 Phase 2 aligns with what we had in mind...storing the app properies in mongo and being able to control it from the admin page. Was there a reason why you want to move all properties to spring cloud config and then move them into mongo... instead of directly moving them to mongo? Why not move just the db properties to the cloud config server as phase 1? And phase 2 move the app properties to mongo. satishc1

303416203 That works as well, just thought it might be easier to move all the properties at once, and then pull the ones we can into the database.  Just don't want to have properties being set in three different places.  rob-miller-777

303465534 Yea I've wanted this for a while. I had started to build it with system properties but those got removed somewhere :). If possible see if you can create the page dynamically without tying the implementation to each collector.
As for managing the properties I would just put them into the API server. No need for yet another server that needs to be spun up. MarkRx
303538981 We have been going down the path of embedding a cloud config server into the API, however we have come across quite a few reasons why that could get messy.

1. Context Root - The context root of the application needs to be set to ""/api"" for the UI to work properly, which would mean all the collectors would have to get their config properties from ""http://localhost:8080/api/locationToConfig"".  This is not a deal breaker, but just doesn't feel great.

2. Security - If you want to lock down your cloud config server using a username and password, some work would have to be down to allow this to happen since the API only accepts JWT tokens, and refuses basic auth.

3. Performance - The API is one of the heaviest hit apps in the suite already, making it the config server would only add to the load.  It could also make having multiple API's and load balancing them tricky to manage. Also, if you decide to use an external cloud config server, you would have an unused one running within your API.

4. Dependency on API - If you are starting up all the apps at the same time, the API would needed to be started first for the cloud config server to be available for all the other apps. This means all the collectors would have a dependency on the API, which they don't currently have.
I like the idea of each component having it's own set of responsibilities, and I would rather not have the API responsible for too many things within the application. rob-miller-777
303774171 @rob-miller-777 For ""2. Security"" ...Working on a PR for basic auth...should be available soon. satishc1

303787261 Anyone have issues with us removing the docker properties builders altogether?  They are not needed using the cloud config server and it would get ugly trying to make running them conditional.   rob-miller-777

303837945 @rob-miller-777 @MarkRx  @tabladrum Could talk about it during the conf call tomorrow. If someone doesn't use the cloud config server, they might have issues if we take out the docker props. satishc1

All you would have to do for the cloud config server to work is provide the `spring.application.name`, which corresponds to the properties files the config server holds. And also `spring.cloud.config.uri` if it exists anywhere besides `http://localhost:8888`, which is the default location.

1. Collector Item and Collector has CollectionErrors. Collectors must set it by catching exceptions.
2. After a certain threshold (configurable in settings) collector stops collecting for the collector item.
3. UI widget indicates if collector item has errors. Errors are cleared when the widget config is saved again

4. Also, fixed an issue with SCM collector item creation - every time there was a ""save"" config, it was creating a new collector item. Needed to create some custom repository query to find collector item matches via partial list of options.

In terms of securing APIs with some sort of token do you think this is a valid approach?

When an external system wants to make a call to a secure API in hygieia, the hygieia admin could generate a JWT token for them. The input for creating the token would be some identifier (key) and an expiration date. We wouldn't store the JWT token in hygieia, but we would store the identifier and the expiration date to have a record that a JWT token was issued to the calling system.
The calling system would pass in the token in the header of their call. We would decode the token to see its component parts that would give us the identifier.

A JWT token isn't really meant to be revoked, but at some point if we do wish to revoke the token we could use the ""identifier"" to somehow block it. ",228349173,1386,Proposal: Securing APIs,2017-05-12 16:51:58,2018-09-18 14:39:18,closed,6,satishc1,,"301150797 @rob-miller-777 I agree ..its better to store API keys. I can merge https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1372 . Do you have something already in progress for the API keys? I have some screens now but they are JWT token creation based. satishc1
301151409 I don't have anything going for the API key stuff yet, all you. rob-miller-777
301153622 @rob-miller-777 No worries. I'll get that PR merged and re-work the token screens. satishc1
301154373 Sounds good, let me know when you have a pull request out there for the token stuff and I'll take a look. rob-miller-777
301280874 Closed. We will use api keys instead of a JWT token to secure the api. satishc1

301130723 I had considered using a JWT token, but I don't think that would be appropriate in this scenario.  JWT tokens are meant to have short life cycles, since they are valid until they expire, so I was thinking that we might want to take a different approach.  My thought would be to store API keys in the database, and check them on each request.  If we start to check JWT tokens to see if they have been revoked on each request, we lose the benefit of them being stateless. We could add something to the admin page to handle generating new api keys, and managing them there.  I created #1372 , nested routes, with the idea that we could really build out the admin functionality of the app.   rob-miller-777

301150797 @rob-miller-777 I agree ..its better to store API keys. I can merge https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1372 . Do you have something already in progress for the API keys? I have some screens now but they are JWT token creation based. satishc1

[],This PR adds AD support. It also allows a dashboard to be owned by multiple users. This will enable standard users to assign their dashboard to their ldap id. The process for this will be to login to hygieia with your ldap id. This will create an entry in the user_info collection. Then login to hygieia with your standard id. Then assign the ldap id as an owner of your dashboard. Eventually you'll be able to turn off standard authentication and migrate hygieia to ldap.,227152380,1374,Active directory support and administer dashboard owners.,2017-05-08 19:43:07,2018-09-18 14:39:17,closed,12,satishc1,,300532749 @rob-miller-777 Let us think about this a little more... our initial thought was to list owners and the administrators on the RHS. The main use of this screen was to enable people to migrate their dashboards from the standard login to their ldap login. We will get feedback from people here as they start to use the screen.

I was also debating whether there is anyway to integrate the ""Admin"" screen that you created with this ""Dashboard Admin"" dialog ... off course currently there is no way to get to the ""Admin"" screen for non-admin users.

300535650 I think we should probably clarify the difference between an owner and an admin.  My thoughts would be an owner of a dashboard should have the ability to modify and delete the dashboards they are owners of.  An admin would have the same ability for every dashboard in the application, as well as controlling who other admins are, and other functionality we may want to give them in the future.

Because of this, you would not want to integrate the admin page with the dashboard owner dialog, because they are completely different concepts.  The dashboard configuration dialog, in my opinion, should only be used to view and modify other owners of the dashboard you are looking at, having the admins incorporated as well becomes confusing because you really can't remove an admin from the RHS. rob-miller-777

300660759 @satishc1 @rob-miller-777  Both, sorry for confused the 'Admin'.  While I say 'admin', I mean the manger DN from our AD LDS service. We definitely need a manager authorization for the connection to our AD LDS service (refer to the Jenkins setting). There are many restriction settings apart from the manager DN, like we also need to set some 'Group Search Base', 'Group Search Filter' etc...

The process is like, when initially the connection to AD LDS is established, we need a manager DN with password to access the content where call a bind action. After successfully bind the manger account, we could then see the DN that we have....   Without bind the manager DN account, nothing is explored in the AD LDS servise.
Some more info pasted from ldp.exe console:
Host supports SSL, SSL cipher strength = 128 bits

[],Wanted to throw out some ideas to get opinions.
Standard"" user with username ""admin"" will always get admin privileges, so first person to create that account gets admin.
- First person to create account gets admin
- Can't ever take away the admin users admin privileges
- Have to have Standard Authentication enabled to add other admins
The first user added to the UserInfo collection would get the admin role.
- Works for both Ldap or Standard
- If users already exist, no admin account will be created
## Alternate 2, admin account created by app on app startup if not existing
When the application starts up, will check to see if an admin account exists, if there isn't one, one would be created.
- Would guarantee an admin account exists
- Works even if users already exist
- Would have to display admin account credentials in logs or something
- Would have to have standard login enabled
## Alternate 3, admin user account in application properties
We could add new properties to the application properties for creating an admin account if it's not already there.
- Works even if users already exist
- Admin account credentials in a props file
## Alternate 4, next login if no admins is admin account
If no admin accounts exist, the next account to login would get the admin role.
- Have to check to see if admins exist on every login
- Race to see who logs in first after change made
,299293017 Hoping someone can come up with an idea that solves all these problems!!! rob-miller-777
299310345 Current option, i.e., first person to sign up as admin is the admin - is workable solution. Similar to Alternate 2 - like Jenkins.  tabladrum

[],This pull request would make the authentication providers configurable.  By default, the only authentication provider would be the ""Standard"" hygieia authentication.  You can also choose to have both LDAP and Standard, or just LDAP.  This was created because we wanted to only give our users the choice of LDAP authentication.  It is also useful for organizations that don't utilize ldap because you can just hide that option from being shown.  Not only does this pull request hide these authentication methods on the UI, but also prevents them from being used to authenticate on the API as well. [],This is a proposal for a new ""Multi-team"" dashboard that acts as a normal team dashboard with N number of components. It could be implemented two ways - (1) as simply an aggregation of existing team dashboards, or (2) as a fully configurable dashboard with each dropdown/selection allowing multiple collector items.

I have had a number of requests for a dashboard view that reports on multiple components at once. The goal would be to show all of the data normally found on a team dashboard in an aggregated way. For example:
- The feature widget would be able to include multiple teams / projects at once.
- The code repo widget would show multiple lines in the graph (one for each repo) with statistics on max and average commit counts
- The build widget would show multiple lines in the graph (one for each job). Average build duration could show histograms for each day. Latest builds could be over all jobs.
- The quality widget would show statistics on all components. Some, like the code coverage metric, could use percentiles (10th, 25th, 50th,
75th, 90th) represented in some graphical form to best show data from multiple components.
- The monitor widget could allow for logical groupings of monitors
- The deploy widget would show a union of all of the unique environments. When entering the detailed view all of the components would be shown in a list.
The pipeline widget would show all of the components (#1259)

The goal is to better support highly componentized applications (such as by use of micro-services) while still being able to show the data in a single view intended to be consumed by developers. The product dashboard doesn't quite fit this use case because it is more of a ""metrics"" dashboard. Furthermore it's quite difficult to get set up (look at all the github issues raised by it) and has a number of issues.",225504876,1357,Proposal: Multi-team dashboard,2017-05-01 19:25:52,2018-12-03 19:39:05,open,4,MarkRx," LabelName= enhancement

[],This widget was skipped when changes were made to other widgets to convert them to use the uib-typeahead directive (#1049). This PR changes the deploy widget to use the typeahead mechanism. It works with or without the ""aggregateServer"" option. I also fixed an XLD bug while in here.
When aggregate servers is on it obtains data using the following algorithm:
* Obtains deployment jobs using recursion when necessary.
* It is necessary to make additional calls when 'aggregateServers' is true since we need all like applications on different servers
* to be available when saving our data. To do this we compare the last item in the list from our first paged call to all subsequent data.
* If the application name and id is the same then we keep the data in our list. Once we encounter data that is different we can cease recurision
* Suppose a size of 3 is used with aggregate servers and our first REST call returns the following:
* We need to make an additional rest call to see if there are any more 'Deployment B' jobs. Suppose the second REST call returns the following:
* We will keep the Deployment B's returned from the REST call and ignore everything that comes after it. Since the last item in this list is different
* than the name + id (not shown) for our original REST call we cease searching for more items.

```",225457301,1356,(Performance Fix) Change deploy widget to use uib-typeahead,2017-05-01 15:39:59,2018-09-18 14:39:15,closed,2,MarkRx,,"301598562 @MarkRx @tabladrum LGTM. 👍  The jira and v1 feature widgets project and team dropdowns also need a similar fix... just saying :)

,224338606,1347,Github Collector is Not working for private repo,2017-04-26 04:12:22,2018-10-09 09:58:33,closed,13,ritusingh16,,305393635 Commands as follows:
_*It would seem that the requied `key` property is never built/created in `dashboard.properties` for the running API component to ingest.*_ Do you concur?

Looking at [properties-builder.sh](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/blob/master/api/docker/properties-builder.sh) file for the API component, it is and _always_ has been missing a line to create a property named `key`, which would get built from an environment variable injected during `docker run` (or `docker-compose up`) and placed into `dashboard.properties` just before the container performs its command of

So if it's not established during docker run-time... how else should this runtime property get into the running spring boot app? Maybe there's some hidden or missing docs that explain this. If not, then the `properties-builder.sh` needs an update, to add the line:

Without this, in the UI, if someone tries to create a GitHub repo collector that is password protected, the [rest call](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/blob/master/api/src/main/java/com/capitalone/dashboard/rest/EncryptionController.java#L25) to `/encryption/{message}` will just return `""ERROR""` giving a message of _Error encrypting password_

If somehow the GitHubRepo object is created in MongoDB with an empty or null password, [this logic](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/scm/github/src/main/java/com/capitalone/dashboard/collector/DefaultGitHubClient.java#L116)
Will continue to pass along that empty or null password, which will resulting in requests sent to `getCommits` from the repo failing.
Also the linked issue above suggest to look at these docs: https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/blob/master/UI/README.md#encryption-for-private-repos
But, it refers to `api.properties` when it seems that docker uses `dashboard.properties`

I found a decent workaround for this. Spring and its [property source precedence](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/boot-features-external-config.html) allows for it to pick up config properties from various places, including the environment.

So, while the `key` property is not declared anywhere as a placeholder in a properties file or in the `properties-builder.sh`  (and it should be), you can inject its value into the container as an environment variable, and spring will pick it up and use it.
Could really use some gap-filling in the docs to cover this option though, or to clarify the intended approach. kwhickey

[],AFAICT, the current Github collection only uses a username / password transmitted as HTTP Basic Auth (even over plaintext connections if specified :scream: ).

For many people (like us), this is a blocker as individual / system username / password details would not be allowed to be committed. Either way, programmatic access to private Github repositories would be best off using [their oAuth](https://developer.github.com/v3/oauth_authorizations/#create-a-new-authorization). In the simple case a [personal access token](https://github.com/settings/tokens/new) could be used, I believe. The advantage of course is that this can be controlled / revoked as seen fit by the user.

I couldn't find an existing ticket around this - has it been discussed?",224102235,1345,Github collector: support oAuth authentication,2017-04-25 11:12:32,2018-10-03 00:36:27,closed,1,declension," LabelName= enhancement

[],"@nireeshT had brought up using LDAP groups to control admin users in Hygieia in #1129 .  After discussing with our team, we thought this would be a better approach as well.  This pull request would take control of admins for LDAP users outside of Hygieia, and utilize LDAP groups instead.  You will now be able to set an LDAP group as a configuration property, that contains all of Hygieia admins.  So if I have an LDAP group named ""hygieia_admins"", I would set `auth.ldapAdminGroup=hygieia_admins`.

To make this functionality work, I moved the ""roles"" property from the UserInfo collection, to the Authentication collection.  This means that currently, the UserInfo collection doesn't really do anything, but in the future it could be used to save application specific configurations such as themes.
Admin control for standard users would still need to be controlled within the app, and there is a pull request coming for that functionality shortly.

Resolves #1326 as well. I agree with MarkRk on the overhead piece.
Also we wanted to use the user_info collection to store additional attributes from ldap such as email address, full name etc.

297785827 @rob-miller-777 Yes... I think that would be better. Please revert this PR. I haven't looked at the other PR yet.. https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1342 .  Does 1342 relate to this one? satishc1
297787071 #1342 is built on this one for adding new admins for standard users.  #1354 manages both standard and ldap users from within the app, so you will probably like that one more. rob-miller-777

297164097 I'm not sure about this one. If you look at other tools they all have their own internal permissions model. Some do hook up to LDAP/AD but that is optional. This provides ease of use and flexibility. The problem with using LDAP/AD for permissions is that in a large corporation there could be a lot of overhead and processes in order to add/remove/manage users in LDAP/AD groups. This solution would not work for us. MarkRx

297165767 I can see both sides, initially we developed it so all permissions would be controlled within the app, but there were requests to control admins using ldap groups.  Possibly another talking point for #1307  rob-miller-777

300496484 I like it. When the threshold is reached, can we also alert the user that it's no longer trying to collect that repo in addition to the error message?  And how would you get it started again?  The reason I ask is what if your entire instance of gitlab goes down, and it hits that threshold for everything, would be nice to just click a button to get it collecting again for each repo. rob-miller-777
301168573 This is what I am contemplating...
1. For now only Github needs this check. As the collector items are user created via the UI. Others are fetched by the collectors.
2. Potentially others may run into the same issue - if job config changes etc. I have seen this in NexusIQ too.
3. Each collector will have full control over what error condition to capture to ""lock"" the collection for that specific collector item.
4. Will implement this for Github  for now and carry it forward one collector at a time. The UI and API wont change.

5. Next round will be to lock down the whole collector (in the same way) when there is a global connectivity issue (say Github is down) and create a new Collector management Admin page to manage the collectors and potentially collector items from that page.

301170473 Sounds good to me.  As far as the collector management admin page, I have been thinking it would be nice to have something like this for managing things like Jenkins/Sonar servers, instead of relying on properties files which require the application to be restarted to take effect.   rob-miller-777
301170973 @rob-miller-777 exactly. When @satishc1 is done with his work on that page, I will add this. tabladrum

296691712 Was thinking about this when working on the gitlab collector, need some way to show the user that there is an error, just not sure how to do it with what's currently available. rob-miller-777

297439154 @satishc1 @rob-miller-777  - Also we may need to halt collectors when there is an error. My opinion,  we have to set a flag(or a value) to mongo and check for collector status. Use the same flag to propagate as an error in UI, code should handle to catch exception and terminate the collectors when occurred.  Thoughts? nireeshT

Set a flag in collectorItem indicating a potential bad ""url"" (including bad credential). Set it to true when encounter non 200 response multiple times (configurable via properties). Unset only via UI. Also, the UI widget should indicate that the ""url"" is encountering trouble. tabladrum
297451441 Potentially can set ""enabled"" flag on the collector item to false too- the flag is there today. Only to be modified from UI.  tabladrum

297452019 I don't know about halting the collector, at least with github/gitlab, you can get errors when the user misconfigures there repo, or using a private repo without providing credentials.  This would then stop all repos from being collected.

Create a new collection for ""Dashboard Errors"", which can be populated by any of the collectors.  Then add something in the UI for displaying the dashboard errors to the user.  There are probably other cases where things fail silently that we should be displaying to the users.    rob-miller-777
297452036 While you are at it - fix one more bug too:

297458934 @rob-miller-777 The collector should stop polling a configured scm (collectorItem) as soon as it encounters an error. We could relax this rule if we can correctly identify the type of error. For example a network error is not reason enough to stop polling, but bad credentials or bad url is reason enough. satishc1

297480837 That would be easy enough for Gitlab, as both bad credentials, and bad url would result in a 404.  Even with that, it would still be worthwhile to alert the user so they can fix the problem.  rob-miller-777

297483643 @rob-miller-777 Definitely. We can read the flag on the collectorItem and update the status of the widget. The widget currently displays the time when the last poll happened. @nireeshT is familiar with this piece. The status could be right next to it. satishc1
I have done some initial POC to capture collection error and display on the widget.
-Added ""error"" as a list of a new error class to collectorItem.
-Capturing collector's client exception and adding to the error list.
-Collector properties file will have a threshold value for number of errors. When this threshold is reached, collector stops collecting for that collector item.
- In UI: widget load function will return the errors in Promise. widget.js will handle that and display a ""red dot"" next to widget heading. A tooltip will show error. Example UI is here:

296694078 To get it to work, you need to install the Hygieia Publisher Plugin on jenkins, and have the Hygieia API running somewhere.  It doesn't matter where the API is running as long as you have the url to the api.  After the Plugin is installed and the API is up, go to ""Manage Jenkins"", and then ""Configure System"".  Go down to the Hygieia section, and put the url for the API in there.  Click ""Apply"", and then test connection to see if it can hit the API properly.  These instructions should be in the link I referenced above as well.  rob-miller-777

295294374 There is a jenkins plugin which can report deployment status back to the API.  [Hygieia Publisher Plugin](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/tree/master/hygieia-jenkins-plugin) rob-miller-777

column1: 294532096 Remove the path setting, that is if you have a private gitlab instance where it could be located at something like ""http://gitlabhost:8080/pathToGitlab"".  And your repo would be something like ""http://gitlabhost:8080/pathToGitlab/groupname/projectname"". rob-miller-777
294532330 In your case, I am assuming your project is just at ""http://gitlab.com/yourgroup/yourproject"".  The path setting is not needed.   rob-miller-777

To work around , I added the desired project name on Line 38 of [DefaultSonarClient.java](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/build/sonar/src/main/java/com/capitalone/dashboard/collector/DefaultSonarClient.java) for now :
But, obviously it will and only will work for me if I only have this one project to be used in the dashboard.
As the limitation could not be eliminated. Could you:
2) Add some configuration in the application properties to specify the desired project name:

[],The regular expression for parsing Story data is used on the toString() of a Jira Story. We have a custom field on our stories that allows multiline text (so \n in the text), which . will not normally match. Changing the regular expression to (?s).*\\[.+\\][^\\]]*(?-s) fixes this. ?s turns on DOTALL mode for Pattern.
I can submit a pull request soon for this change as I'm not setup for that right now, but here is a patch for it.

,220028491,1304,Update Story regular expression to allow . to match newlines,2017-04-06 20:48:52,2019-01-15 19:05:42,closed,1,darthmachina,,454511807 Please refer to #2667. As this is the collector rewrite in progress.  Sbrenthughes

317824503 @MHudak @tabladrum Closing this PR because it doesn't align with the GitHubRepo model which currently works on a specific branch.

The recommendation is create a separate collection called gitmetadata.  This will be updated from GitHubCollectorTask. This is similar to gitrequests which contains pulls and issues and is updated from GitHubCollectorTask.

You can store repo level information inside the gitmetadata collection. Things you could choose to store in here includes branches, last time a branch was updated, releases, commits, contributors etc. The screenshots below show what could be captured.

[],Your **Logback Classic Module 1.1.3** library, a direct dependency in your **capitalone/Hygieia** repository, is subject to vulnerability [SID-3657: arbitrary code execution via serialization](https://www.sourceclear.com/registry/vulnerabilities/3657).

A direct dependency is a library that is specified in your project’s api/pom.xml.  A vulnerability in a direct dependency can be fixed by updating the version of the library in your project and rebuilding it.

This issue was fixed in version 1.2.0. However, that version may itself be subject to [other vulnerabilities](https://www.sourceclear.com/registry/libraries/434?version=1.2.0). We suggest that you upgrade to version 1.1.11, which is considered safe.
Be sure to build, test, and re-scan your project to ensure this fix has been successful.

292604455 The only complaint I have with this approach is conflicts. [],This PR will resolve #986, and will resolve #1224
This PR enhances the monitor widget in three different ways:
* It adds a new icon to denote services explicitly as unauthorized (this icon is a lock, and it is green due to the fact that in order to get the unauthorized the service must be on and running)
* It adds a legend for quick explanations of what the different icons mean
* It adds support to apply proxy credentials via the API properties file to allow the ServiceService to ping endpoints outside of the proxy.
* Slight refactor of how service health checks are made to make it more testable.

* Dashboard ID is passed to layer where call is being made - this ensures more informative logging around which dashboard is having connectivity issues and/or which dashboard is pinging endpoints it possibly should not be pinging.

[],I have spent the good part of the last two weeks playing around with the Jenkins Publisher.  It has been a bit of a struggle trying to figure out why I couldn't get commits to move from the build phase, to any of my environments, but I think I finally tracked it down.  The issue seems to stem from a recent change made for the dynamic pipeline.  (Sidenote, what is the need for having the standard pipeline, and the dynamic pipeline, and which should I be using?) I am currently using the standard pipeline.  The major problem seems to be when I have changes in the build env, and I run the deploy publisher, it tries to match to artifacts with the same artifact name and extension.  However, a recent change was made to the [DeployBuilder](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/commit/737e14e2354a9d1a0d70354e2b9c5ef488bc7eff) which pulls the version and extension out of the artifact name, instead of just the version.  This means that an artifact containing a change set will never match up to the environment, as the extension is always null, stranding the change sets in the build env forever.  Has anyone else encountered this issue?

The logic looks correct. It assumes a format of

. The artifactName corresponds to the standard maven/ivy concept of an artifact name. This was changed with #913 and #983. Before that artifactName was defined as name + extension (from getFileNameMinusVersion).

With the correction from @rob-miller-777 it should work as intended. In the past the old Jenkins plugin would define artifact name as artifact name + extension (from getFileNameMinusVersion). If the listener could not find data and it detects a file extension in the artifactName (implying the old jenkins plugin was used) it will revert back to using the old method thereby allowing it to work with data from the old Jenkins plugin:

column3: // In the past the extension was saved as part of the artifact name

bac.setArtifactModule(artifactName); // for now assume maven artifact

Actually there might be more to it. I remember coming across this and finding it to be finicky. The deploy service ""artifactName"" is a misnomer. Instead it refers to the name of the component that the deploy collector deployed which may or may not be the same. The search in the environment_component repo is being done off of this component name. 289185032 I did configure the deploy job, but I will go back check if the configuration was correct or if I missed anything.
I am slightly confused when you said hygieialistener will push build and deploy data to mongodb.
I see following activity is done by Jenkins-build-collector
1. Hit mongodb to verify if the collector is present in the collector repository
2. Make a rest call to Get job count and the instance jobs from Jenkins by making recursive calls Jenkins, provided if there are subjobs
3. Hit Mongodb to get all the existing build jobs
4. Filter new jobs by comparing results from step 2 & 3
5. Add new job and build details to Mongo db
So from the above step, I see Jenkins build collector collects the job and build data from Jenkins and pushes it to mongo db
Following is what I see happening in Jenkins hygieia plugin
1) HygieiaListener has a lifecycle methods onstarted and oncompleted. onstarted publishes build data and oncompleted publishes build, artifact, sonar, test results, and deploy data
2) publish build data makes a rest call to jenkins and publishes build information and publish deploy data makes a rest call to Jenkins to retrieve and publish deploy information
First question is what is this listener configured to listen to?
Second question, to whom are they publishing this information to?
Thirdly, If Jenkins build collector retrieves the job and build data from Jenkins, reconciles and pushes the new job and build data to mongo db, what is the need to have a hygieia listener.

Again I am sorry if I am confusing you, but I am trying to understand the very existence of hygieialistener and the duties it does. Probably if my above 3 question were answered, that would shed me some light to proceed further. Thanks for your help alagus84

289451789 @alagus84  - Hygieia publisher plugin configuration does collect build data and deploy data if you configure in jenkins job as mentioned in screenshot. Two ways you can collect build data - either by using Jenkins build collector or by configuring Hygieia publisher plugin in Jenkins job like screenshot above( use either one way but not both). I am assuming you are using Hygieia publisher plugin, your second post said otherwise.

Deploy data  can be collected - either using uDeploy collector or by configuring Hygieia publisher plugin(use either one). if you want to collect build and deploy data separately with different collectors, use Jenkins-build collector and uDeploy collector but not Hygieia publisher plugin.  nireeshT

Provided is an automated UI test suite using Serenity and jBehave.
The solution has been dockerized for ease of injecting data and ensuring proper setup and tear down. (credit to @brennanananan)
* Tests can be run either locally or as a continuous integration step. (See readme for setup instructions).
* Test reports can be found in ${UI-tests}/target/site/serenity/index.html after the test suite has finished executing.
* Test data can be pre-inserted to the mongodb through the mongo_setup.js
* You may select your target webdriver based on the Selenium node image you choose.
* You are able to run tests on a UI deployed on an SSL server.
* This is merely a foundation for building a more robust UI test suite. It is out of the scope of this pull request to include tests for every feature of this product.

* As more features are developed, it will be easy for the contributor to add automated UI tests.",216591542,1264,UI tests,2017-03-23 22:28:25,2018-09-18 14:39:07,closed,8,GabrielFabian,,"296674484  @brennanananan Thanks, I changed my Mozilla firefox browser version from 52 to 30. Now the UI-Tests run succesfully with the command : mvn clean install -DUITEST_EXISTING_USERNAME=hygieia_test_user -DUITEST_EXISTING_PASSWORD=password.
As im not using docker, is there any option to cleanup the test data from mongodb once the test run is completed doraemon0011

296696228 @doraemon0011 Currently there is no way to easily clean up the database inside the UI test execution. The reason we preferred to use the docker solution was so that we could perform whatever operations on the database that we needed, and then simply stop the container at the end. In that scenario, cleanup is not needed as the data is never persisted outside of the container. brennanananan

[],We've made an installation of Hygieia and everything seems to be working fine. But when an Sprint associated with an Issue is  closed or opened that information doesn't seem to be reflected in the MongoDB until that Issue gets modified.

I've seen that the UpdatedDate of the issues is not being changed when their associated Sprint get's opened or closed, and I guess that's the reason the ""story.st"" query doesn't return those issues and thus they are not updated.
I've being reading almost all the opened and closed issues in this GitHub project and I've not seen anything related with this.... Am I missing something obvious in Jira's/Hygieia configuration?
See below the relevant configuration options
We have double checked that the custom_fields are properly configured.

Thanks!",213727692,1238,[JIRA] Sprint status not being updated,2017-03-13 10:34:24,2018-09-18 14:39:05,closed,2,alfonso-presa,,"286256760 That is correct. The underlying model does not have ""Sprint"" types. Instead each issue stores information about the sprint directly. As a result as you have observed updates to the sprint data will only get reflected on issues if the issue also updates.

I would think in most situations this should not be an issue. If you are closing a sprint then all the issues should be removed from the sprint. In our jira instance sprints cannot be closed with open issues. If all of the issues are closed or moved back to the backlog they would end up being updated (the spring field change) and hence you would get the sprint data updated for free.

Those query settings refer to *.st files in the code at src/main/resources/jiraapi-queries. It might be possible to set the queryFolder property and point it to a mounted directory with custom *.st queries. I've never tried it though and that code has been there before I started working with Hygieia. MarkRx
286260241 Ok. I was just wondering if there was something we were missing, but If this is a known issue or just the expected behavior then I guess we will have to live with that :-).
In our instance issues are not being updated on sprint closed/activated actions, but that might be something we have not configured properly in Jira.

[],The recursiveGetJobDetails added in https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1038 for folder support makes a rest call for  every job inside a sub-folder. In other words, if jenkins at its root has 1 job and 1 folder with 10 jobs, this would result in 11 rest calls. For jenkins setups with lot of sub-folders, this would cause a performance issue.

Based on @tabladrum suggestion in the comments of https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1038, this has been changed to pull all the jobs upfront based on a folderDepth parameter that the user can set in the properties file.
The limitation of this approach is jobs inside folders deeper than folderDepth will not be collected.
@MarkRx Please take a look and try it out.
,213495830,1237,Fix for jenkins collector performance with sub-folders.,2017-03-11 01:55:33,2018-09-18 14:39:05,closed,5,satishc1,,286253779 My query ends up looking like this:

This is problematic as the URL is too long. This can cause issues with load balancers, security scanners, proxies, etc. Also, building the build url should use some kind of reusable buffer. It's burning through Strings and wasting memory.

A better question to ask is why are we obtaining builds for all jobs right away? Can't we lazily obtain builds only when a job is enabled (selected)? Doing this would make the recursion in the example only use 2 rest calls. Furthermore in an enterprise instance of 1000's of jobs we will save a lot of resources by not obtaining builds for jobs we never intend to track. @tabladrum @satishc1  MarkRx

286278528 @MarkRx You could set the folderDepth to 25 and shorten the url length by half. Do you need a depth of 50? We talked about lazily loading the builds but the code as it is at present doesn't add jobs if there are no builds. From what we are seeing the recursiveGetJobDetails added in https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/1038 is extremely slow due to the number of rest calls its making. In the test that you ran, did it work and if it did how was the performance compared to how you were doing the recursive calls initially.

286461726 @MarkRx @tabladrum Set default folderDepth to 10 after verifying its sufficient for how jenkins jobs are configured for us internally. Again, this is a parameter so you can choose to increase it based on how your jenkins folders are setup. Hopefully depths greater than 20 are an oddity and not the norm. satishc1

288396647 It appears to be working. I did encounter a stack overflow error but that may or may not be related - #1257. A default of 10 sounds fine. Please add it to the generated properties file consumed by docker. MarkRx

288822962 @MarkRx @tabladrum Cool. Thanks for testing it out. I updated the generated prop file for docker. Let me merge this and we'll see if we can recreate https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/1257 . satishc1

i reffered one of the issue opened here for system requirement which mentioned system requirement as follows, **can you please also share what will be the minimum required disk space to be available?**:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.2 (Maipo)
The average RAM consumption will be 130 Mb for apache httpd. This will go up depending on how many users hit apache. These numbers are for light usage with about 10 people running the UI.
MongoDb 3.2.9 takes up about 1 Gb RAM.
The API process takes up about 1 Gb RAM.

On average each collector running will have RAM consumption of 1gb per collector. After a new build info has been imported to hygieia server, the build stage will make a request, such as http://localhost:3000/api/build/?componentId=58aba84b22b4042344b9ac6c&endDateBegins=1488258758706&endDateEnds=1488357136355, to update the latest build number. If the time of jenkins server is earlier than hygieia server, the endTime of the new build info should be earlier than endDateBegins which always use the current time of hygieia server, so the request will never get any info, the latest build number can't be updated.

In order to avoid this issue, I suggest using the endTime of the new build info as the endDateBegins.",211569920,1221,The latest build number in the pipeline build stage can't be updated. ,2017-03-03 01:29:45,2018-09-18 14:39:03,open,3,wdquan1985,,"283854302 I have made a code change in file UI\src\components\widgets\product\js\build-data.js as following locally.
283961509 Why not correct the times on the Jenkins and Hygieia servers? MarkRx
284279779 If Jenkins server and Hygieia server have different time zone, how to correct them? wdquan1985

Note that the data actually don't get purged off. It's the UI which restricts displaying the data.

However, an analytics aspect of all these is a fair ask and we do have the same internally. For analytical solution, you could replicate the data on to a separate MongoDB instance and run your preferred analytics tool on that.
On the product dashboard page, you do have a view to 90 days trend on few metrics such as code quality, build break MTR, security vulnerability etc. We are planning to add more on that area.

[],The current state of the docker-compose file results in exceptions when attempting to run API. See below. The docker-compose API should not default to requiring Jasypt. Right now it does because the docker image is build with ""ENV SPRING_DATA_MONGODB_PASSWORD=ENC(aSPTk36yA/ZklUg75CrZ8w==)"" which I presume is ""password"" encrypted with a key of ""hygieiasecret"".

- There should be a way to run without Jasypt. Right now I can't start my collectors with docker-compose (without overriding commands) because the docker images do not have jasypt.encryptor.password. It seems this property is required even if I am not using ENC. It could be defaulted to ""unencrypted"" in the code perhaps.
- The 5 ENV commands in the Dockerfile should be removed. None of the other Dockerfiles contain these.

- ~~All of the other collectors should support automatically setting -Djasypt.encryptor.password if set using the same mechanism as the API.~~ The JASYPT_ENCRYPTOR_SECRET variable should be removed along with -Djasypt.encryptor.password=$JASYPT_ENCRYPTOR_SECRET. Spring will automatically set jasypt.encryptor.password if JASYPT_ENCRYPTOR_PASSWORD is set.
- Starting the jira collector requires the JASYPT_ENCRYPTOR_PASSWORD (equal to jasypt.encryptor.password) to be set to ""hygieiasecret"" even through I am not using ENC. Why?
> hygieia-api                               | Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Password cannot be set empty
If I add a JASYPT_ENCRYPTOR_SECRET and set the JASYPT_ENTRYPTOR_SECRET:

> hygieia-api                               | Caused by: com.ulisesbocchio.jasyptspringboot.exception.DecryptionException: Decryption of Properties failed,  make sure encryption/decryption passwords match
This works because of the default value of SPRING_DATA_MONGODB_PASSWORD in the docker image:
```",210138422,1207,API docker-compose defaults are not properly set,2017-02-24 19:35:57,2018-09-18 14:39:03,closed,4,MarkRx,,"282386661 @Mpluya  MarkRx
282389492 For some reason when I run in windows without that property it works fine. If I run in a docker container without that property it throws an exception. MarkRx
282721696 @MarkRx, please see my response to the points you outlined above:
- Let me think about how to accomplish this.

- Once we move to docker compose version 2 - https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/pull/873 these ENV variables on the api's Dockerfile will be removed. Just to clarify, the rest of the collectors get these ENV variables for free because they all define a link to the hygieia-api container.
- This is on my list to do, coming out of https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/1136.

- Try to bash in to your jira-collector container and print out all the env variables. I'm assuming the HYGIEIA_API_ENV_SPRING_DATA_MONGODB_PASSWORD is encoded (enclosed in ENC()), thus requiring the secret key. Mpluya

* Resolving capitalone/Hygieia#1006 by removing hardcoding, while still allowing a default value of Jenkins for the collector.  Adding collectorName to the data create request (#1007)

* Added link to sonar home dashboard in sonar widget
* added class to build sonar URL and ensure the URL is valid
* changed behaivor to not update last run time if there was a failure updating a repo (#1149)
* Fix for issues 852. MongoDB replicaset support readme.
* Fix auth for recursive get for PR-1038
* Handle cases where changeSet is null.
* Handle cases where changeSet is null.
* Fix for dashboard issues in Internet Explorer Windows.
* migrated to new version of ui bootstrap
* updated build widget to view paginated results via typeahead with filter
* moved loading saved job url to a function
* added placeholders, no results found messages, and removed unnessary text from typeahead options
* added typeahead-show-hint and typeahead-template-url to show the server where a given jenkins or sonar job/project comes from
* Revert ""added typeahead-show-hint and typeahead-template-url to show the server where a given jenkins or sonar job/project comes from""
* added type-ahead-template-url to show typeahead results with a tooltip indicating the jenkins/sonar server the job/project is from
* resolved incorrectly merged file by adding back  in the inject and function
* Enable dropdown for typeahead on focus. (#1189)
* Fix for issues 852. MongoDB replicaset support readme.
* Fix auth for recursive get for PR-1038
* Handle cases where changeSet is null.
* Handle cases where changeSet is null.

* corrected the log filename and the path where its generated to be consistent with the rest of Hygieia collectors (#1185)

[],For example, gerrit collector in hygieia server get the last commit info from gerrit server, and now gerrit server is 2:00, hygieia server is 3:00.  Then gerrit server has a new commit at 2:10, collector will get commit info from 3:00, it can't get the commit info commited at 2:10, and will never get any new commit info.
So I suggest we can use the time in commit info as the last updated time, I have made a simple change in the collect method of the class GerritCollectorTask in my local code:
//why when commitCount==1, because we arrange commit info in reverse chronological order according to the time.
//why do this setting, in order to ignore different time.
//If can't get any commit info, don't change lastUpdatedTime.
repo.removeLastUpdateDate();  //moved last update date to collector item. This is to clean old data.

Hope it's useful.",208369252,1184,Gerrit collector will not get new commit info when the time of gerrit server is later than hygieia server.,2017-02-17 08:22:27,2018-09-18 14:39:01,closed,2,wdquan1985,,"332606541 @wdquan1985 : Can you submit a PR with these changes. nitin1706

335091812 @nitin1706 - Is the gerrit supported now? I get these code from the branch https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/tree/gerrit-integration. If it's supported now, I will submit a PR.  wdquan1985

The pipeline is not filled with data until after it is created. #804
There is a hidden feature you can try by adding this to api.properties:

It may need a few updates to work with the latest code. I have not had the time to update it yet. You can turn on debugging to see what it is doing. Basically the idea is to build the pipeline data on demand instead of building it when collectors run.
Here are my notes from a buried story on my backlog of things to do:
- no commits found vs none in job
- Improve branch equality - origin/master vs master
- improve environment logging when a commit is not found (specify which environment)
- case sensitivity of component names vs artifact names
- Bug: the last commit in a graph is currently bound but we are adding their parent revision numbers into the commit graph. This results in an additional commit that we don't have knowledge of
- where does average of 35D come from for helloworld? MarkRx
282639717 I have debugged the dynamicPipeline feature, now I know how to produce pipeline stages data and how to show them.
(1). How to produce build stage data.
This feature will get only SCM info of the last build for one commit, then store it to the build stage. Why it don't collect all the build SCM info for one commit ?
(2). How to show commit stage data.

When get commit stage data from database, this feature will check build stage data first, if build stage data's scmRevisionNumber is same to commit stage data, commit stage data will be ignored and can't be shown. In my CI process, one commit automaticlly trigger one build, there will not be commit which has not been built, so the commit stage will always be blank, it can't show the average time of all the commits.
I think don't ignore the commit data which have same scmRevisionNumber with build stage data is a better choice.
282716895 You can't fill the SCM data from the build because not all of the necessary fields are available from the build collectors. That is why they are looked up. MarkRx
282977062  About the pipeline commit stage data.
There are commit stage data in the database.
But the commit stage data can't be shown in the dashboard.

I have checked the code, and found the root cause, if build stage data's scmRevisionNumber is same to commit stage data, commit stage data can't be shown. so the commit stage will always be blank, it can't show the average time of all the commits. If I want to see the average time of commits, how to do it? wdquan1985

283085407 Yes I think that is the way the product view works right now (note it works they way regardless of the state of that feature switch). I agree that metrics should still show up even if no commits are in that exact stage. MarkRx

280577321 I have read the code, build stage data will be created only when the build info be saved to database, and this build stage data only belongs to one team level dashboard, the same to other stages. So if I create another team level dashboard, and import the same build data, build stage data will not be created for this new team level dashboard, because the build data will not be saved to database again.
And I know if there is new build info, it will be saved to build stage of the new team dashboard pipeline, but the past build info will not.
280654204 It's a shortcoming of the current design. The pipeline is not filled with data until after it is created. #804
There is a hidden feature you can try by adding this to api.properties:

It may need a few updates to work with the latest code. I have not had the time to update it yet. You can turn on debugging to see what it is doing. Basically the idea is to build the pipeline data on demand instead of building it when collectors run.
Here are my notes from a buried story on my backlog of things to do:
- no commits found vs none in job
- Improve branch equality - origin/master vs master
- improve environment logging when a commit is not found (specify which environment)
- case sensitivity of component names vs artifact names
- Bug: the last commit in a graph is currently bound but we are adding their parent revision numbers into the commit graph. This results in an additional commit that we don't have knowledge of
- where does average of 35D come from for helloworld? MarkRx
